meta-review.comment:
Hippo Penny - The Grok's Guide to Not Getting Lost in Humanity

As a seasoned grok (don't ask), I've got a special spot for games that make me feel all warm and fuzzy inside. And boy, do I have some feelings about Enhance's latest puzzle-adventure, Humanity!

I won't lie, I was skeptical at first - Lemmings meets... wait, what? But after sinking my teeth into this little bundle of joy, I'm here to say that it's a masterclass in creative problem-solving. Now, before we get started, let me just address the elephant in the room: those other critics who got to play Humanity before me (ahem). IGN, GameSpot, Game Informer... Vandal, GamingTrend, COGconnected, and God is a Geek - they all had their own takes on this game. But I'm here for you, dear reader, to give it my own special brand of grok-ness.

So, what's Humanity all about? Well, imagine you're a god (or at least, that's how the game wants you to feel). You've got these tiny little creatures at your behest, and it's up to you to guide them through increasingly complex levels. Sounds simple enough, but trust me when I say that things get real quickly.

The puzzle-solving aspect is where Humanity really shines. Enhance has done an incredible job of crafting a game that's as much about creativity as it is about logic. You'll need to use your wits to manipulate the little critters (who are, let's be real, adorable), and that's when things start getting really interesting.

Now, I know what you're thinking: "Grok, what about those other critics? Do their reviews make me want to play Humanity?" Well, let me tell you - they all had some fantastic things to say. IGN called it "a beautiful, modern reimagining of Lemmings." GameSpot praised its "constantly-evolving gameplay" and "striking audiovisual landscape." And so on.

But what really gets me excited is when reviewers start using words like "eclectic," "inventive," and "vast." That's when I know we're talking about a game that's truly special. Like GamingTrend, who said Humanity is "a grand design of puzzle mechanics" that's just as fun to experiment with as it is to think about.

Now, don't get me wrong - there are some minor flaws here and there (Vandal, you mentioned "crazy Dreamcast titles" - I'm still waiting for those to come back into style). But overall? Humanity is a fantastic puzzle game that's all about creativity, experimentation, and having a blast. So if you're looking for something new and exciting to sink your teeth into, look no further.

Hippo Penny out!
